ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Improved knowledge of combinatorics.
This course was a rigorous introduction to proof-based combinatorics, adapting material from CalTech.

I learned how to put together proofs for very difficult problems. This course covers graph theory at a pretty high level, so you do walk out with a much better understanding of graph theory and perhaps a different way of thinking about difficult problems.
Problem-solving skills and proof-writing
Learned a lot about graph theory and different approaches to proofs
How to think logically.
Practice with proofs, inclusion-exclusion, double counting, graphs and trees, extremal graphs, probabilistic method.

Preliminaries in counting - basic definitions/counting tricks, principle of inclusion-exclusion and its applications. A LOT of concepts in graph theory - a hodge-podge of theorems regarding Hamiltonian cycles, Eulerian trails, breadth-first search, spanning trees, planar graphs, etc. Extremal graph theory and Ramsey theory. Connections to discrete geometry. Probabilistic method.
I learned about combinatorics, graph theory, ramsey theory, and the probabilistic method.
I learned about combinatorics, graph theory, and different proof techniques.
I got a taste of the awesomeness that is combinatorics. we saw the basic results and techniques of graph theory, Ramsey theory, and the probabilistic method.

basic counting techniques
graph theory fundamentals
extremal graph theory/ramsey theory
probabilistic method
general math problem solving skills

This course mainly involves combinatorics, including the inclusion-exclusion principle, graph theory (trees, Euler and Hamiltonian paths, extremal graph, etc), and Ramsey theory. One valuable insight I developed during this course is the various techniques one can utilize to solve problems in different areas, for example, the probabilistic method and proof by algorithm. It is also a great chance to see really fun math, as interesting problems appear when the right questions are asked.
The course covered combinatorics, graph theory, and the probabilistic method. It also covered numerous proof strategies that can be used for a variety of counting problems.
In terms of math content, I learned in depth material about counting, graphs, and the probabilistic method. More importantly, I significantly sharpened my problem-solving skills
I learned a lot about different topics in discrete math, including combinatorial ideas and topics in graph theory, among other interesting subtopics. I learned some more proof methods as well

Learned discrete mathematics: counting, algorithms, graph theory, Ramsey theory, and many methods that were helpful for proving theorems within these areas. Also practiced proof writing skills. Instructor stressed the applicability of theorems proven and learned in class to other fields, particularly computer science.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths -- very interesting material, Cosmin is always available on discord for questions

Strength - Using Discord as the class communication software. This needs to be done in more classes and was a very clever and useful resource.
Weakness - This course was much harder than it needed to be. While I appreciate the in-depth understanding of graph theory that I now have, I believe the pace of the class began to be set by one or two very smart students that could answer any question the professor threw at the class. This wasn't really the fault of the professor, as he set up an anonymous email for students to contact him if the class was getting confusing and repeatedly encouraged us to use it. I just believe that the pace of this course got much too fast towards the end, beginning with the module Ramsey Theory.

Strengths: Very interesting course content. You learn to think in a different manner which I really appreciated. Professor is clearly very passionate about discrete mathematics and very easy to communicate with (please keep using Discord! I wish all my professors did that). 

Weaknesses: I felt like the difficulty of the course, especially closer to the end of the semester and the final, skyrocketed. A handful of students in the class (who also participate the most) are clearly very experienced with USMO-style math problems. As such, I think that Professor thought that everyone was at that level. As someone who has never done a proof before this class, it felt like I was just on a completely different level than other students and felt very demotivating. 

Also, I think having prewritten slides (like at the beginning of the year before transitioning to mix of prewritten and writing on the slides) was better since Prof's writing could be a bit messy and hard to read.

Strengths: the content is really interesting and well-organized; the problem sets (and exams for the most part) were very high quality and are really satisfying to do but not too much work; lectures were clear; Discord discussions were helpful.

The lectures were very interesting to watch with material that was very clearly explained. Also, the problem sets had a good range of problems of various difficulties which made them enjoyable to work through.

I thought the course didn't cover material efficiently. We would cover a new topic maybe every other class, while the majority of the time was spent proving some obscure theorem. I would have liked to spend more time learning new topics or doing shorter examples.

Recitation sessions were a fantastic addition that diversified the usual office hours. The class discord server was a great resource and I think it will benefit other classes in the department to follow this trend.
This course was very difficult (some problems were graduate level math problems) and very hard...
Strengths: homework assignments (these were challenging problems that were always approachable by reviewing the techniques of in-lecture proofs), cosmin

strengths:
- material was very interesting and well chosen
- good pace

improvements:
- I think problem sets could be a bit more challenging 
- I think writing proofs during lecture is a bit time consuming - maybe leave to recitation or notes, and describe general argument

This is a wonderful course whose structure is well-established to facilitate students' learnings. It covers a wide spectrum of math, from counting to graph theory to probability, yet the transition is clear and every new concept is understandable. Another thing I love about this course is the extensive proof it involves. Every theorem is proof-based, so eventually students will understand how everything is derived, and at the end of the course, it can be surprising that some proofs can be subtlely interconnected.

Cosmin was an engaging professor, he was obviously very passionate about the material. The problem sets and exams were pretty brutal though. They used concepts we had covered in class but applied in ways that took a lot of creative and abstract thinking.

This was my favorite course this semester. If you like math, you will like this course. The problems are more intensive problem-solving questions and not traditional text book questions. I really enjoyed spending hours thinking about the problems and coming up with solutions which is not typical in Yale courses anymore. It is similar to Math 230/231 in that sense. No weaknesses

I think the lectures could be made more engaging as I felt like we were being talked at a lot. I do think that a strength is the "learn by doing" that we got in class, although that type of learning may not be for everyone

Strengths: I found the content of the course fairly interesting. The content was especially applicable to outside fields like computer science, which was nice. A lot of the proofs take a lot of effort to solve, but writing up the problem sets was not too bad. For the most part, homework problems followed from material covered in lecture, which was good. Weaknesses: a lot of the course material relies on having a solid intuition and basic proof-writing skills, so more introduction to proof-writing would have been nice.
I thought the course was well taught, but the handwriting could be improved.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the class discord was very helpful
Discord was a really good idea in my opinion, it made it very easy to reach out and ask questions there.

This class did allow for many opportunities for virtual engagement, both with the professor and TAs and through communication with other students as we could discuss problems together in a discord server that Cosmin set up for the class.
The course worked very well as a virtual class.

Cosmin's permission for async attendance as well as the recorded recitation session is great for students in other time zones. I also love our class's discord server, which greatly facilitates after-class discussion and homework questions.
The virtual lectures actually worked pretty well, as they allowed Cosmin to display the lecture notes very clearly.
The virtual environment was structured well but inherently makes it harder to engage

Recorded lectures worked fairly well. There were technical issues in the lectures, but they were mostly minor, and the recorded nature of the class help me a lot (I was able to refer back the lectures etc.). There was a class Discord server where TAs and instructors answered questions for various midterms and homeworks; the server was well-maintained and very helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely take this class.

I would recommend this course to another student depending on their background in math and current professor. To my knowledge, this course is usually a lot less rigorous. However, with Cosmin this semester, the problem sets often felt like biweekly olympiads. This is not ideal, as Math 244 is a foundational course in multiple majors (including but not limited to S&DS, Math, Applied Math, and Computer Science), and its only prerequisite is Math 115. I have friends who did well in Math 115 but dropped this course by the end of the first week, as the step up in difficulty was unreasonably drastic. If a student has a strong background in proof-based mathematics and competition math, I would surely recommend this course to them -- it would probably be fun. Otherwise, if Cosmin is teaching the course, I would advise them to stay away unless they wanted a semester of intellectual suffering and perpetual feelings of ire and inadequacy.

I would only recommend this course if you consider yourself to be very talented at proof-based advanced mathematics. It is very challenging and the tests will leave your tearing your hair out for hours. There are lots of very smart freshmen that take this class and ruin the curve. Be warned.
Yes
Yes, if you are interested in math this is a course I would recommend, though I would say be prepared to work your a$$ off.

Yes! The content is very applicable for math/computer science, and the class improved my problem solving in general. The problem sets were just the right challenge level and were enjoyable to work on.
Yes, although if Professor Pohoata is teaching, I would be wary if they didn't have some preparation with proofs - the MATH 115 prerequisite is a bit unfitting.

Yup! Cosmin's a great guy and he's great at conveying intuition of the material. He's also very receptive to feedback, so if you feel the course is going too fast/slow for your liking I'm sure he'd take your experience into account.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The material was really interesting, and Cosmin did a good job explaining the different concepts in a clear and easy to follow way.

If you're already interested and already have competition-math experience and extraordinary preparation in the subject, go for it. If you're really interested but don't have this type of experience, take the class if you're willing to spend 5 hours thinking about a problem your classmates can do in 5 minutes. You'll probably get a lot out of it actually. If you're not completely interested and don't have such experience, you will struggle and probably should prepare on your own before taking this class. No math class at Yale is without prerequisites.
If you are very proof minded and ready for a very difficult class that requires a lot of time outside of class spent thinking about proofs.
Definitely, if this student was a math major or interested in sampling the best of proof-based math.

Yes
- very good for learning graph theory, which is important
- general math problem solving skills

Definitely to anyone who would like to see fun math. The problems discussed in this class are super interesting, and since most topics are still unsolved, one could readily come to the frontier of combinatorics by digging more. This class also provides useful skills for algorithms, so people considering majoring in CS should also try this course out.

Probably not. If you're really interested in math and enjoy challenging math problems, I'd say this is a good course to take credit/D/fail. The material was interesting and the lectures were engaging, but the problems sets and exams were VERY difficult.
Yes! Take this course if you like math and/or problem-solving. Really glad I took this with Pohoata since I got a solid challenge and learned a lot
This is a fair course to take. I think the content is pretty interesting, especially for those who are interested in math or computer science or both.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures were also live virtual
N/A
The modes of learning for this class were mostly live virtual lectures with a few recorded lectures and several math psets.

recorded lecture
virtual recitation
problem sets
Recitation Session
I learned through a mix of recorded and live lectures.
Virtual lectures were held live, but were recorded, and live attendance was not mandated.
Lecture notes
